Organization members understand their roles and responsibilities around security and privacy.

","details":"

{{organization.name}} Personnel Security Policy

1.0 Purpose

This policy establishes the {{organization.name}} Personnel Security Policy for managing risks from personnel screening, onboarding, termination, transfer and management. The Personnel Security Policy helps the organization implement security best practices concerning personnel processes and events.

2.0 Scope

The scope of this policy applies to all employees, workers and contractors (collectively referred to as “users” or “personnel” in this policy) at {{organization.name}}. 

3.0 Policy

All recruitment shall be done after careful scrutiny and examination.

All users shall have a contractual agreement with {{organization.name}} for not divulging any confidential or sensitive information to any unauthorized parties.

Roles and responsibilities shall be defined in a job description highlighting the responsibilities and required skills for specific roles and communicated to individuals. {{organization.name}} shall conduct periodic training and awareness programs for all users on information security responsibilities.

3.1 Pre-Employment Checks

The organization shall carry out background and/or reference checks on all employees in accordance with relevant laws, regulations and ethics, and proportional to the business requirements. 

3.2 Terms and Conditions of Employment or Engagement

The terms and conditions of employment or engagement with {{organization.name}} shall mandate compliance and acknowledgment of the Information Security policies by all users. This shall include a clause requiring users to protect the confidentiality of information, both during and after cessation of employment or contract with {{organization.name}}.

All users must be aware of their security responsibilities and reporting lines by acknowledging the acceptable use agreement and through formal security awareness training.

All terms and conditions of employment shall comply with the legal requirements under the relevant jurisdiction.

Demographic Diversity, Interdisciplinary Roles and Competencies: {{organization.name}} shall Implement hiring practices that prioritize candidates with diverse demographic backgrounds (gender, race, ethnicity, age, and other dimensions of diversity) and skill sets relevant to AI, including but not limited to data science, engineering, ethics, and social sciences.
 
Collaboration with Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Accessibility (DEIA) Initiatives: {{organization.name}} shall incentivize AI actors to collaborate with existing nondiscrimination, accessibility and accommodation, human resource functions, employee resource groups (ERGs), and DEIA initiatives.

3.3 During Employment 

{{organization.name}} shall conduct annual performance evaluations by the end of each calendar year for employees that have been with the organization for more than a year. Respective supervisors shall perform these formal performance evaluations at least annually based on the criteria and objectives outlined in the job descriptions.

Review of job descriptions shall be performed, and any changes shall be communicated to individuals by {{organization.name}} management. 

3.4 Termination

The organization shall consider creating a separation agreement to safeguard {{organization.name}} and its customers’ Intellectual Property Rights and confidential information at the time of terminating their employment or business relationship with {{organization.name}}. The organization must, upon personnel termination, at least:

  • Remove their access from any systems or applications that process sensitive information in a timely manner.
  • Revoke all digital certificates.
  • Ensure all tokens or smart cards issued are returned.
  • Ensure that keys and IDs provided to them during their employment are returned.
  • Remove all physical access to the facilities.
  • Ensure that all devices, hardware and other material provided to them are returned.

3.5 Contractors

All contractors engaged with {{organization.name}} shall have a contractual agreement in place with {{organization.name}} for not divulging any confidential or sensitive information to any unauthorized parties both during and after the cessation of the contract with {{organization.name}}.

The terms and conditions of engagement with {{organization.name}} shall mandate compliance with Information Security policies. In addition, contractors shall acknowledge their security responsibilities through acceptable use agreements.

4.0 Security Awareness and Training Program

{{organization.name}} must establish formal information security and privacy awareness, education and training programs for all employees and, where relevant, contractors and/or third parties, appropriate for their assigned job functions before authorizing access to any organizational information systems or performing any duties. 

Employees shall undergo mandatory security and privacy awareness training at hire or at least annually or after significant changes (whichever is earliest), and records of such training shall be maintained. 

All {{organization.name}} employees are required to annually acknowledge that they have read and understood the security and privacy policies and procedures. Specialized training is scheduled at defined intervals for different units in the organization and/or when there are significant changes to the information systems.

The organization institutes regular risk assessments and uses industry best practices in remediation.

","details":"

{{organization.name}} Risk Assessment Policy

1.0 Purpose

Information security risk management is the process of identifying, evaluating and treating risks around the organization’s valuable information (including personal data). It addresses uncertainties around information assets to ensure the desired business outcomes are achieved. As a result, this policy establishes information security risk management requirements to perform periodic Risk Assessments (RAs) to determine security risks in corporate operations, products and services and initiate appropriate remediation.

2.0 Scope

This policy applies to all operations, products, services, information assets and information systems that are owned and operated by {{organization.name}}, including (but not limited to) applications, databases, servers and networks, and any process or procedure by which these systems are administered and/or maintained. RAs can be conducted on any entity within {{organization.name}} or any outside entity that has signed a third-party agreement with {{organization.name}}.

3.0 Policy

{{organization.name}} shall establish a risk management framework aligned with business objectives that establish rules governing how to identify risks, assign risk ownership, how the risks impact the confidentiality, integrity and availability of the information and the method of treatment for identified risks. A formal risk assessment methodology shall be approved by management.

The risk management framework shall include guidelines for identifying and estimating the cost of protective measures to eliminate or reduce the security risks to an acceptable level.

All operations, products, services, information assets and information systems that are owned and operated by {{organization.name}} must be assessed for risks that result from threats to the integrity, availability and confidentiality of {{organization.name}}’s data. Organization shall purchase a cyber security insurance policy that includes coverage for incident response and recovery activities.

The risk assessment shall be conducted/reviewed periodically, and any changes shall be communicated to relevant individuals/teams as appropriate. In addition, an assessment shall be performed under each of the following circumstances:

  • When new purchases, acquisitions or procurements are made
  • As part of the system development/modification/upgrade process
  • When changes are to be made to the infrastructure (e.g., remodel, additions, installations, etc.)
  • When there are changes in the regulatory, economic and physical environments as well as changes in vendor and business partner relationships

Assignment of responsibilities for risk assessment shall include the appropriate participation of executive, technical and other management staff, as necessary.

Risks identified during a risk assessment shall be assigned to a risk owner (person or entity with the accountability and authority to manage the risk), and identified risks must be mitigated or accepted prior to the system being placed into operation. 

{{organization.name}}’s management shall periodically review the status of risk management activities and mitigation plans.

4.0 Risk Management Activities

At a minimum, the risk management program shall focus on the following five types of activities:

  • Identification of Strategic Objectives: The alignment of strategic objectives and risk management is essential to avoid a siloed risk management approach. This is the key step in performing risk assessments. 
  • Identification of Risks: A continuous effort to identify which risks are likely to affect {{organization.name}}’s strategic objectives and consequently security functions and business continuity of {{organization.name}} and documenting their characteristics.
  • Analysis of Risks: An estimation of the probability (likelihood), impact and prioritization of risks relative to each other. Review the risk management results periodically or whenever there are significant changes to the information system or other conditions that may impact the security state of the system.
  • Mitigation Planning: Decisions and actions that will reduce the impact of risks and limit the probability of their occurrence or improve the response to a risk occurrence.
  • Tracking and Controlling Risks: Collection and reporting of status information about risks and their mitigation plans, response to changes in risks over time, and management oversight of corrective measures taken in accordance with the mitigation plan.

5.0 Responsibilities

System owners and department managers or supervisors are responsible for conducting a risk assessment as well as prioritizing, implementing and maintaining the appropriate risk-reduction measures defined in the risk assessment process.

Risk owners are the individuals who are ultimately accountable for ensuring the risk is managed appropriately. Multiple personnel may have direct responsibility for or oversight of, activities to manage each identified risk and collaborate with the accountable risk owner in their risk management efforts.

Executive Management is responsible for sponsoring and supporting the risk management plan and processes, participating in the risk management meetings, and reviewing and approving risk assessments and risk mitigation plans.

Responsibilities for the continued development, implementation and maintenance of the risk management program shall also be assigned internally.

The organization manages, configures and protects organization servers and hosts based on industry best practices.

","details":"

{{organization.name}} Server Security Policy

1.0 Purpose 

The purpose of this policy is to establish standards for the base configuration of servers (physical and virtual) owned and/or operated by {{organization.name}}. Effective implementation of this policy will minimize unauthorized access to {{organization.name}}’s proprietary information and technology.

2.0 Scope

This policy applies to servers owned and/or operated by {{organization.name}} and to servers registered under any {{organization.name}} owned internal network domain.

Cloud-based service providers (AWS, Azure, GCP, etc.) have a shared responsibility model. Understand the responsibilities of the provider and your responsibilities when it comes to server security. Typically the provider is responsible for the security of the data center and the underlying hardware, and {{organization.name} is responsible for the security of the virtualized servers running on the hardware.

3.0 Policy 

3.1 Ownership and Responsibilities 

An organizational unit or group must own all servers managed by {{organization.name}}. Approved server configuration guides must be established and maintained by each operational group based on business needs and approved by {{organization.name}} IT. Operational groups should monitor configuration compliance and implement an exception policy tailored to their environment. Each operational group must establish a process for changing the configuration guides, including review and approval by {{organization.name}} IT.

Physical servers shall be registered within a corporate enterprise management system. At a minimum, the following information is required to identify the point of contact positively:

  • Server contact(s) and location, and a backup contact
  • Hardware and Operating System/Version
  • Main functions and applications, if applicable
  • Information in the corporate enterprise management system must be kept up to date
  • Configuration changes for production servers must follow the appropriate change management procedures

Virtual servers should be tagged with the following information:

  • Owner unit or group
  • Main functions and applications, if applicable
  • Environment (production, staging, dev, etc.)

3.2 General Configuration and Backup Guidelines 

Operating System configuration should be following approved guidelines. Services and applications that will not be used must be disabled where practical. 

  • Access to services should be logged and protected through access-control methods (firewalls, security groups, ACLs, etc.).
  • The most recent security patches must be installed on the system as soon as practicable, the only exception being when the immediate application would interfere with business requirements. 
  • Trust relationships between systems are a security risk and their use should be avoided. Trust relationships should not be used when some other method of communication will do. 
  • Standard security principles of least required access to perform a function will always be used. Root should not be used when a non-privileged account is acceptable. 
  • If a methodology for secure channel connection is available (i.e., technically feasible), privileged access must be performed over secure channels (e.g., encrypted network connections using SSH or IPSec). 
  • Server hardware should be located in an access-controlled environment.
  • Servers are specifically prohibited from operating from uncontrolled publicly accessible areas. 
  • Production servers shall be backed up daily.
  • For servers that require fewer backups, the frequency for regular backups of such servers should be defined.
  • Production servers should not be on the same network segment as non-production servers—the greater the separation between production and non-production servers, the better. 
  • Configuration changes should be managed using a change management tool.
  • Configuration changes for production servers must follow the appropriate change management procedures.
 

3.3 Monitoring

All security-related events on critical or sensitive systems must be logged, and audit trails saved as follows:

  • Logs are enabled for all servers, including logging configuration changes.
  • Logs should be sent to a central log management platform, preferably in a separate environment with more strict security controls.
  • Logs are accessible only to appropriate applications and trusted users.
  • A review of logs shall be done with read-only access tools (e.g., view, more, less, graphical web tools for accessing/filtering logs, etc.)
  • All security-related logs are retained online for a minimum of 90 days.
  • Security-related events should be reported to {{organization.name}} IT, who will review logs and report incidents to IT management. Corrective measures will be prescribed as needed. Security-related events include, but are not limited to:
    • Port-scan attacks
    • Evidence of unauthorized access to privileged accounts
    • Anomalous occurrences that are not related to specific applications on the host
    • Loss or breach of sensitive data
  • The servers shall be monitored for capacity and performance requirements. The incident management process shall be followed for confirmed events and anomalies.
  • Forecasts of future processing demand of system components should be made on an ongoing basis and compared with schedule capacity. In addition, forecasts shall be reviewed and approved by IT management. Change requests must be initiated as needed based on approved forecasts.

3.4 Patch Management 

All servers under {{organization.name}}’s control will be maintained with the latest security patches to their operating systems and key applications. 

Each organizational unit or group is responsible for servers under its control. When a patch is available, an authorized system administrator must enter a change ticket according to {{organization.name}}’s Change Management Policy. All patches should be tested (where applicable) on test systems before being rolled out to production, where possible.

In case patches cannot follow the defined schedule, a document must be produced explaining why the patch must be deferred. Permissible deferrals may include a lack of appropriate change windows within the appropriate timeframe or a conflict with other critical changes scheduled at that time. Approvals shall be granted by a senior member of the IT team. 

IT/Information Security is responsible for performing a vulnerability scan on systems after each patch window to show that the patches were installed correctly.  Vulnerability scan reports should be reviewed periodically.

3.5 Decommissioning a Server

  • {{organization.name}} shall define a process for decommissioning servers. This process will be different for virtual servers and physical servers.
  • The data on the servers must be completely destroyed before the machine is taken out of service. The machine should be labeled accordingly.
  • Ensure the shared responsibility with cloud providers and how cloud providers delete customer data when a virtual server is deleted.
  • Ensure cloud provider(s) have appropriate controls around wiping and destruction of hardware.

3.6 Compliance 

Periodic audits will be performed as authorized by {{organization.name}} management. Efforts will be made to prevent audits from causing operational failures or disruptions.

{{organization.name}} Software Development Policy

1.0 Purpose

The purpose of the Systems Development Life Cycle (SDLC) policy is to describe the requirements for developing and/or implementing software and systems in {{organization.name}} and to ensure that all development work is compliant as it relates to any and all regulatory, statutory, and/or contractual guidelines. This document establishes guidelines for the development of software and systems that are required to be applied to all developments to ensure their maintainability, security and protection against cyber-attacks and accessibility. 

This policy provides for secure and privacy-aware methodologies during the design and implementation of {{organization.name}}  products and services. It incorporates best practices in software and operations design and implementation processes with security, privacy and vulnerability reviews throughout their lifecycle so that implementation ensures that {{organization.name}} products are only used as intended and are not vulnerable to attack or abuse. The goal of {{organization.name}} software practices is to maintain the confidentiality, integrity and availability of information resources in order to enable secure and successful business operations.

2.0 Scope

This policy covers all development activities carried out by the DevOps team during the design, implementation and maintenance of {{organization.name}} products and services. {{organization.name}} follows a branching strategy workflow for source control and uses the principles outlined in the OWASP Secure Coding Practices to train the DevOps team and defend against the OWASP Top 10 security vulnerabilities.

3.0 Policy

3.1 Design Process

{{organization.name}} DevOps team will consider the security implications of any feature development and/or enhancement to ensure the security and stability of {{organization.name}}’s application. Things to consider are:

  • How can this feature be misused?
  • Does this feature cause unnecessary data exposure?
  • Does this feature expose an attack vector?
  • Are the data sources used by the feature trusted or untrusted?
  • Does the feature follow the privacy principles of:
    • Data minimization? (Is only strictly necessary personal information collected, used, stored, and transferred by the feature?)
    • Purpose specification? (Is the existence of the feature, its usage of the personal information and the reasons why it processes the personal information captured by the Privacy Policy?)
    • Use, retention and disclosure?  (Does the feature use the personal information, store it and disclose it in ways which are compatible with the purpose(s) for which it is designed?)

3.2 Development Process

{{organization.name}} DevOps follows a streamlined branching strategy designed for continuous delivery. Secure coding practices are enforced using static analysis, dynamic analysis, and dependency scanning tools integrated within the CI/CD pipeline.

3.2.1 Feature Development

  • Lightweight Specifications: Features to be developed are described with brief user stories or issue descriptions focused on user outcomes. Technical specifications, if needed, should be concise.
  • Feature Toggles: Incorporate feature toggles/flags to enable deployment of incomplete work to staging or production environments (behind a toggle) for early testing and feedback.
  • Feature Branches: Feature branches should be short-lived and merged into master within a few days. During the development process, changes from master should be integrated into the feature branch on an ongoing basis.

3.2.2 Pull Requests

Pull Requests (PRs) are the primary mechanism for code review and integration in our continuous delivery environment. To ensure quality and timely integration, the following requirements apply to all pull requests:

  • Automated Reviews:
    • Code analysis tools (e.g., static code checkers)
    • Unit tests
    • Security scans (e.g., dependency scanning for vulnerabilities)
  • Successful execution of these automated checks is mandatory before a PR can be merged into the master branch. Results must be addressed within the PR.
  • Asynchronous Review: While senior developer review remains valuable, the focus should be on code quality, architecture, and integration considerations. Leverage the automated test suite and linting tools to catch common errors.

3.2.2.1 Additional Considerations:

  • Reviewers should not be the same person who authored the PR.
  • Pull request comments should document any new dependencies introduced or database migration requirements.

3.2.2.2 Post-Review Actions

Once the pull request is reviewed, it can be:

  • Approved and merged into master: The reviewer comments on the PR indicating approval.
  • Rejected with changes: The reviewer comments with necessary changes. After changes are made by the developer, the PR will be re-reviewed for approval.

After a pull request is reviewed, approved, and merged, the associated feature branch may be deleted.

3.2.2.3 Merge Strategy

To maintain a clear and easy-to-follow code history, developers must follow the following guideliens for how pull requests are merged:

  • Fast-forward and Squash Merges Preferred: For clean and linear Git history, we recommend using fast-forward merges or squash merges whenever possible. These merge strategies minimize the number of commits in the master branch, making it easier to track code evolution.
  • Branch Merges (With Caution): Branch merges should only be used in rare cases where preserving the individual commits in the feature branch is crucial. This could be for debugging purposes or if the feature branch has a complex history that needs to be maintained separately.

3.2.2.3 Commit Message Formatting

For "final" commit messages that will be included in the master branch history, developers shall follow the LKML guidelines for informative commit messages. These guidelines emphasize a short subject line describing the change followed by a more detailed body explaining the reasoning and potential impact. Please also observe the following best practices as outlined at https://cbea.ms/git-commit/

  • Separate subject from body with a blank line
  • Limit the subject line to 50 characters
  • Capitalize the subject line
  • Do not end the subject line with a period
  • Use the imperative mood in the subject line
  • Wrap the body at 72 characters
  • Use the body to explain what and why vs. how

3.2.3 Releases

To manage releases in a continuous deployment environment, the following steps shall be followed:

  1. Tag for Release: When code on the master branch is considered production-ready, a new release tag shall be created following semantic versioning principles (e.g., v1.2.0).
  2. Create Release: A new Release shall be drafted and linked to the created tag. The release shall include detailed notes outlining all relevant changes.
  3. Trigger Deployment: The CI/CD pipeline will be automatically executed upon the new release, handling the build, test, and deployment process to production.
  4. Monitor Post-Release: Production systems shall be closely monitored to quickly identify and address any issues that may arise after deployment.

3.2.4 Hotfixes

When a critical bug is discovered in production, developers shall follow the following procedure for expedited hotfixes:

  1. Hotfix Branch: Create a hotfix branch directly off the master branch. Clearly name it to indicate its purpose (e.g., hotfix/critical-security-issue).
  2. Apply Fix: Implement the fix on the hotfix branch.
  3. Pull Request: Create a pull request to merge the hotfix into master. While standard reviews apply, prioritize urgency in this case.
  4. Automated Deployment: The CI/CD pipeline will automatically build, test, and deploy the hotfix to production once it's merged into master.
  5. Tag for Tracking: Although a full release isn't necessary, create a release tag on master to track the hotfix deployment.
  6. Regression Testing: Write a test case, if applicable, to prevent the bug from reappearing. Integrate this test into your automated test suite.

3.2.5 Branching Strategy Summary

{{organization.name}}'s branching strategy promotes rapid releases and continuous deployment:

  • Master Branch: The master branch always reflects the latest, production-ready code.
  • Feature Branches: Short-lived feature branches are created directly from master. Use clear naming conventions (e.g., feature/new-widget).
  • Pull Requests: Once a feature is complete, create a pull request to merge back into master. Automated tests and code reviews are mandatory.
  • Continuous Deployment: Approved and merged pull requests automatically trigger the CI/CD pipeline, which deploys changes to production.
  • Hotfixes: If critical, hotfixes branch from master, follow a fast-track pull request process, and are immediately deployed upon merging.

Key Principles

  • Small, Frequent Changes: Encourages smaller, well-tested features that can be rapidly deployed.
  • Automation: CI/CD pipeline handles testing, build, and deployment for every change to master.
  • Monitoring: Robust monitoring and logging are essential for quick detection and rollback if needed.

3.3 Service Vulnerability Reviews

Products and services released by {{organization.name}} require regular reviews for vulnerabilities and attacks. 

  • External scan and penetration tests will be performed annually.
  • A severity rating system and process shall be established to prioritize application vulnerabilities for root cause and ensure remediation.

3.4 Data Processing Input Validation

All data processing inputs are defined, including the source and criteria for processing. All data processed by the {{organization.name}} application is collected directly by the application.

All data processing tasks include a data validation step confirming the integrity of the data to be processed. Data integrity is enforced at the application level.

Input fields in the {{organization.name}} application are validated on both the client side and the server side for proper formatting, data type and expected values. The definitive source for data validation is on the trusted system (server). Invalid data will be rejected by the server.

All data inputs must be validated for:

  • Character encoding.
  • Acceptable header/cookie values.
  • Expected data types/ranges/lengths/valid values.
  • Allowed characters.

User supplied data must never be passed to any dynamic execution function.

3.4.1 Data Processing Schedules

Data processing schedules are defined within the {{organization.name}} application. The results of the processing tasks should be logged and reviewed periodically. Errors and/or exceptions encountered in the processing task generate a detailed exception email that is sent to the DevOps team for remediation.

3.5 Authentication and Password Management

{{organization.name}} adheres to the following practices for secure authentication and management of user passwords:

3.5.1 General Authentication

  • Authentication is mandatory for all resources and systems within the organization's infrastructure, excluding those explicitly designated as public.
  • Authentication mechanisms shall be enforced by trusted systems designed to fail securely in the event of errors or unauthorized attempts.

3.5.2 Password Storage

  • All passwords must be stored using a robust one-way cryptographic hash function specifically designed for password hashing, such as Argon2id, scrypt, or bcrypt.
  • Passwords shall be salted with a unique, randomly generated salt per user prior to hashing.

3.5.3 Password Complexity

  • Where possible, user passwords must meet the following complexity requirements:
    • Minimum length of 12 characters.
    • Mixture of uppercase, lowercase, numbers, and special characters.
    • Passwords must not be found in lists of commonly used, leaked, or easily guessed passwords.

3.5.4 Account Lockout

  • User accounts shall be temporarily disabled after a predefined number of consecutive failed login attempts (e.g., 5 attempts within a 15-minute timeframe).
  • Lockout durations shall escalate with subsequent failed attempts.
  • A secure mechanism for users to self-reset or unlock their accounts shall be provided.

3.5.5 Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)

  • Multi-factor authentication (MFA) should be available for all users and all access types, and must be required for administrative access and any remote access to the organization's systems.
  • Preferred MFA methods include hardware tokens or authenticator applications. SMS-based MFA should be used only as a last resort.

3.5.6 Session Management

  • User sessions shall expire after a period of inactivity (e.g., 30 minutes of inactivity)
  • Absolute session timeouts shall be enforced (e.g., maximum session length of 8 hours)
  • Sensitive operations shall require session re-authentication.

3.5.7 Additional Security Measures

  • {{organization.name}} shall implement a centralized identity management system (e.g., LDAP, Active Directory, Single Sign-On solution) for improved user management and access control.
  • 3.5.7.1 Access to systems and resources shall be governed by a role-based access control (RBAC) or attribute-based access control (ABAC) framework.
  • 3.5.7.2 Regular password audits shall be performed to identify weak, reused, or potentially compromised passwords.
  • 3.5.7.3 A breach notification procedure shall be established to inform relevant users and potentially regulatory bodies in the event of a data breach that compromises user credentials.

3.6 Access Management

{{organization.name}} enforces the following access management principles to protect systems and data:

3.6.1 Access Token Handling

  • Access tokens shall be generated exclusively on trusted systems with proven security measures.
  • Access token identifiers must use cryptographically secure random number generators (CSPRNG) to ensure unpredictability.
  • Token expiration times shall be strictly enforced, striking a balance between security and user experience. Shorter expirations are preferred, aligned with risk tolerance.
  • Upon successful re-authentication, a new access token must be generated, invalidating the previous token.
  • Access tokens shall never be transmitted over insecure channels (e.g., unencrypted HTTP). Transport Layer Security (TLS) is mandatory.
  • User logout functionality must securely revoke all active access tokens associated with that user's session.

3.6.2 Secure Access Control

  • Access to all resources shall be governed by a principle of least privilege.
  • Robust access control mechanisms (RBAC or ABAC) shall be implemented and centrally managed.
  • All API requests, without exception, must undergo access control list (ACL) verification. ACLs shall consider both user permissions and relevant organizational context.
  • Access control logic shall be designed with a "fail-closed" approach, ensuring that unauthorized access attempts are denied by default.

3.6.3 Production Deployment Safeguards

  • The production deployment branch (or branches) must be protected with strict access controls.
  • Changes to the production branch shall require mandatory code reviews and automated testing before deployment.
  • Direct, unreviewed pushes to the production branch shall be prohibited.

3.6.4 Password Management

  • Hardcoding passwords within scripts, configuration files, or custom source code is strictly forbidden.
  • Secure mechanisms such as password vaults or environment variable-based secrets management shall be used for handling sensitive credentials.

3.6.5 Additional Considerations

  • Zero Trust: Explore the implementation of Zero Trust principles to minimize implicit trust assumptions within the network perimeter.
  • API Security: Employ comprehensive API security best practices, including input validation, rate limiting, and robust logging and monitoring.
  • Regular Audits: Conduct regular audits of access permissions, user roles, and privileged accounts, ensuring alignment with the least privilege principle.

3.7 Error Handling, Logging, and Observability

{{organization.name}} implements robust error handling, comprehensive logging, and integrated observability practices to safeguard sensitive information, facilitate rapid troubleshooting, and support incident response. We prioritize the use of open standards for instrumentation and data collection:

3.7.1 Error Handling

  • User-Facing Errors: Error messages displayed to users must be generic and avoid revealing any internal system details or sensitive data that could be exploited by attackers.
  • Sanitization: Log files and any error output must be sanitized to ensure they never contain passwords, API keys, session tokens, or other sensitive credentials.
  • Production vs. Non-Production: Detailed error messages with stack traces may be exposed in development and testing environments, but never in production.

3.7.2 Logging, Observability, and OpenTelemetry

  • Centralized Logging: Logs from all systems shall be aggregated into a centralized log management system, ideally one integrated into a broader observability platform.
  • Logging Levels: Employ a structured logging scheme with clear severity levels (e.g., DEBUG, INFO, WARN, ERROR, CRITICAL).
  • OpenTelemetry Instrumentation: Utilize OpenTelemetry (OTel) for instrumenting applications and infrastructure, aiming to collect logs, metrics, and traces.
  • Essential Log Data: Log entries shall include, at a minimum:
    • Timestamp with timezone
    • System or component identifier
    • User identifier (if relevant)
    • Event description
    • Severity level
    • IP address or source identifier
    • OpenTelemetry Trace IDs and Span IDs: For distributed tracing and correlation
  • Access Controls: Access to log files and the observability platform must be restricted to authorized personnel, with role-based permissions enforced.
  • Retention and Rotation: Define a log retention policy aligned with security, operational, and potential compliance requirements. Implement log rotation procedures.

3.7.3 Additional Considerations

  • Input Validation: Log data from user input should be treated as untrusted and subject to input validation to prevent log injection attacks.
  • Audit Logging: Maintain separate audit logs focused on security-related events (logins, privilege changes, data access, etc.), ensuring these integrate with observability systems.
  • Log Analysis, Alerting, and Tracing:
    • Configure automated alerting for critical events or anomalous activity.
    • Leverage observability tools to visually correlate OTel data, allowing for rapid debugging across distributed environments.

3.8 Data Protection

{{organization.name}} is committed to safeguarding data throughout its lifecycle. The following principles form the foundation of our data protection practices:

3.8.1 Principle of Least Privilege

  • Access to data shall be granted on a need-to-know basis, with permissions strictly aligned with job responsibilities.
  • Role-based or attribute-based access control (RBAC or ABAC) models shall be used to enforce granular permissions.

3.8.2 Data Minimization

  • Collection and storage of sensitive data shall be limited to what is strictly necessary to fulfill business purposes.
  • Temporary data copies must be securely erased immediately after their intended use.

3.8.3 Credential Protection

  • Passwords and other sensitive credentials shall never be stored in plaintext. Use robust, modern password hashing algorithms specifically designed for the task (e.g., Argon2id, scrypt, bcrypt).
  • Each password or credential must utilize a unique, cryptographically random salt.

3.8.4 Data in Transit

  • All data transmission, internally and externally, must occur over secure, encrypted channels using Transport Layer Security (TLS).

3.8.5 Web Application Security

  • Prevent Data Exposure: Client-side code shall be stripped of application comments that could reveal sensitive information.
  • Avoid GET Parameters: Never transmit sensitive data within GET request parameters.
  • Manage Caching: Properly configure response headers to disable caching on any pages that display or process sensitive information.

3.8.6 Data in Non-Production Environments

  • The use of production data in non-production environments (e.g., development or testing) is strongly discouraged.
  • If absolutely necessary, production data must be:
    • Masked or de-identified to protect any personally identifiable information (PII) or sensitive data.
    • Access restricted exclusively to authorized personnel.
    • Usage subject to documented approvals and justifications.

3.9 Communication Security

{{organization.name}} is committed to safeguarding data in transit. The following principles guide our communication security practices:

3.9.1 Mandatory Encryption

  • All communication of sensitive data, both internally and externally, must occur exclusively over encrypted channels.
  • Transport Layer Security (TLS) is the mandated encryption protocol. Use version 1.2 or higher, with a strong focus on the most recent stable versions (e.g., TLS 1.3).

3.9.2 Cipher Suite Configuration

  • Only modern, strong cipher suites shall be supported. Disable legacy cipher suites known to be vulnerable.
  • Regularly review and update supported cipher suites as new vulnerabilities emerge or standards evolve.
  • Resources like Mozilla's SSL Configuration Generator can aid in selecting secure TLS configurations.

3.9.3 Certificate Management

  • Use valid, trusted certificates issued by recognized Certificate Authorities (CAs) for all TLS connections.
  • Employ certificate pinning (with caution) or mechanisms like Certificate Transparency Logs for added verification.
  • Implement robust certificate lifecycle management, including timely renewals and revocation processes.

3.9.4 Fail Secure

  • Never allow fallback to plaintext communication if a TLS connection fails. Systems must always negotiate a secure, encrypted connection according to the configured cipher suites.

3.9.5 Additional Considerations

  • Web Applications:
    • Enforce the use of HTTPS for all web traffic. Use HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) headers to prevent downgrade attacks.
  • Email:
    • For sensitive email communications, consider email encryption solutions such as S/MIME or PGP. Be aware of the complexities of email key management.
  • API Endpoints:
    • Implement authentication and authorization mechanisms on external APIs and enforce the strict use of TLS.

Cross-Reference: This policy aligns with and extends guidelines set forth in the Key Management and Cryptography Policy.

4.0 Customer Notification

As currently available products and services are regularly assessed and reviewed, {{organization.name}} will notify the designated customer contacts within 24 hours if a high-risk vulnerability is found. {{organization.name}} will provide a plan to address the issue and a timeline for when the software or service will have a solution available. Emergency updates will be available in the form of a hotfix patch deployed to the affected system.

 

Appendix 1

1.0 Open Source Software Components

1.1 Licensing

{{organization.name}} shall only permit the use of “permissive” open source licenses. “Copyleft” licenses cannot be used without approval from the appropriate departments at {{organization.name}}.

Acceptable licenses:

  1. Apache 2.0
  2. BSD
  3. MIT
  4. ISC
  5. Zlib
  6. WTFPL
  7. 0BSD
  8. CC0

Acceptable (Python API only)

  1. MPL 2.0
  2. LGPL
  3. LGPL 2.0
  4. LGPL 3.0
  5. Python Software Foundation License (PSF-2.0)

Unacceptable licenses (unless approved by {{organization.name}}):

  1. AGPL-3.0
  2. CPAL-1.0
  3. EUPL-1.2

1.2 Usage

When importing or using open source software, specify a specific version or release.

Importing open source libraries for use in {{organization.name}}’s product must follow a version pattern that specifies a specific version or version range. The use of an open-ended version string (ex, ‘>’) or matching any version (ex, `*`) is disallowed.

{{organization.name}}’s change management and software development life cycle policies are still enforced when developing and deploying open source changes.

1.3 Management and risk categorization

{{organization.name}}’s IT team is responsible for maintaining a list of all open source software in use at {{organization.name}}. Categorize the importance of the various open source code libraries/software in use from a risk or functionality perspective and apply appropriate change control to these categories. Any significant changes to existing open source software needs to be approved by {{organization.name}}, following the standard change management process.

To request a new open source license be approved, submit a request with a link to the open source project, and the reason for requesting inclusion of the license.

Each open source project must have a designated owner. The owner is responsible for maintaining the open source project in {{organization.name}}, including monitoring for security updates, testing new releases, and approving changes to the version in use.

1.4 Security

All open source projects in use at {{organization.name}} must follow, at a minimum, the same security standards as software developed in-house or greater, depending on the risk categorization level.

A tool to monitor and alert on vulnerabilities of open source software in use must be implemented. Tools or services must be configured to scan and alert the open source project owner of any vulnerabilities.

Vulnerabilities identified in open source software must be assessed and risks should be remediated, accepted or use of the software should be terminated.

The organization actively manages risks around third-party vendors and their access to the organization's data.

","details":"

{{organization.name}} Vendor Management Policy

1.0 Purpose

This policy establishes guidelines for the secure management of vendor relationships to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of {{organization.name}}'s information systems and data. This policy encompasses both on-premises vendors and cloud service providers (CSPs).

2.0 Scope

This policy applies to all business relationships where a third-party is granted access to {{organization.name}}'s sensitive information, IT assets, infrastructure, and/or facilities where client data may reside. This includes Software-as-a-Service (SaaS), Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS), Infrastructure-as-a-Service(IaaS), and other cloud-based solutions.

3.0 Policy

3.1 Risk Assessment and Mitigation

  • Risk Assessment: Before engaging with a vendor, a comprehensive risk assessment shall be conducted and approved by management. This assessment must consider:
    • Information Security Risks: Vendor's security, privacy, and confidentiality controls.
    • Operational Risks: Business continuity, facility access, change management.
    • Data Exposure Risks: Data classification and handling procedures.
    • Regulatory Compliance Risks: Impact of the vendor on the organization's compliance obligations.
    • Supply Chain Risks: Due diligence on vendor's own third-party relationships.
  • Risk Mitigation: Risks identified shall be documented, along with mitigation strategies or a determination of risk acceptance.

3.2 Vendor Classification

  • Vendor Inventory: {{organization.name}} shall maintain a centralized vendor inventory listing each vendor, their provided services, and their risk classification (e.g., Low, Medium, High). This inventory shall be updated at least annually or when significant changes occur.
  • Classification Criteria: Vendors shall be classified based on the sensitivity of data handled, criticality of their services, regulatory requirements, and the risk assessment outcome.

3.3 Contracts and Agreements

  • Data Protection Clauses: Contracts must include data protection provisions, stipulating confidentiality, security, and privacy obligations aligned with applicable laws and regulations (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA, etc.).
  • Security Standards: Contracts shall outline the specific security standards or frameworks the vendor must adhere to (e.g., SOC 2 Type II, ISO 27001, NIST CSF).
  • Audit Rights: {{organization.name}} reserves the right to audit or request independent security reports from vendors, particularly for those in the High-risk classification.
  • Incident Response: Vendors are contractually obligated to notify {{organization.name}} immediately in the event of a suspected or confirmed security breach. The contract shall define notification timelines and expectations for vendor participation in incident response.
  • Termination Clauses: Contracts must specify procedures for secure data return or destruction upon termination, along with revocation of all system and facility access.

3.4 Vendor Oversight and Monitoring

  • Vendor Performance Reviews: Designated personnel shall regularly review vendor performance against contractual obligations and security requirements. Review mechanisms may include, but are not limited to:
    • Analysis of vendor-supplied security compliance reports.
    • Vendor-completed security questionnaires.
    • On-site audits or assessments (for high-risk vendors).
  • Periodic Risk Reassessment: Formal risk reassessments for each vendor shall be conducted on a schedule determined by their risk classification. High-risk vendors shall be re-assessed more frequently.
  • Management Reporting: Staff responsible for vendor oversight shall provide reports to management in case of new vendors, change in assessment or change in utilization, enabling informed decision-making and corrective actions, if necessary.

The organization conducts scheduled application and network scanning and penetration tests.

","details":"

{{organization.name}} Vulnerability and Penetration Testing Policy

1.0 Purpose 

The purpose of this policy is to set baseline requirements regarding application and network security scanning and penetration tests offered by external security vendors. 

Audits must be conducted to: 

  • Ensure integrity, confidentiality and availability of information and resources.
  • Investigate possible security incidents.
  • Ensure conformance to {{organization.name}}'s security policies.
  • Monitor user or system activity, where appropriate. 

2.0 Scope 

This policy covers all infrastructure and networks owned or operated by {{organization.name}}. This policy also covers any infrastructure that is present on networks owned or managed by {{organization.name}}, but which may not be owned or operated by {{organization.name}}. 

If segmentation is used to isolate the Cardholder Data Environment (CDE) from other networks, perform penetration tests at least annually and after any changes to segmentation controls/methods to verify that the segmentation methods are operational and effective, and isolate all out-of-scope systems from systems in the CDE.

3.0 Policy 

3.1 Vulnerability Scan and Penetration Testing Frequency

All networks shall be scanned for vulnerabilities on a consistent scan schedule and also on a by-request or as-needed basis or when new vulnerabilities potentially affecting the system/applications are identified and reported

{{organization.name}} may perform penetration testing annually and/or after any significant infrastructure or application upgrade or modification (such as an operating system upgrade or a web server added to the environment).

After vulnerabilities are identified and documented, {{organization.name}} shall establish a process for timely correction of vulnerability based on severity levels.

Exploitable vulnerabilities found during penetration testing are corrected, and testing is repeated to verify the remediation.

{{Organization}} shall identify industry-recognized sources for security vulnerability information, including computer emergency response teams (CERTs). Then vulnerabilities shall be assigned a risk ranking based on industry best practices and consideration of potential impact. 

3.2 Scan Targets

All devices connected to both public and private segments of the network can be scanned. The organization shall outline the breadth and depth (scope) of its scanning coverage, the breadth can be quantified as a percentage of system components, classification of systems, the criticality of systems, or the total number of vulnerabilities to be evaluated while the depth can be defined as level of the system design that the organization intends to monitor (e.g., module, subsystem, component, element).

3.3 External Vendors for Vulnerability Scanning and Penetration Testing

Before performing a penetration testing exercise or vulnerability scan (if using a third-party), {{organization.name}} has to provide formal approval to allow any external vendor to access its infrastructure. 

The third-party vendor will provide a detailed description of the scope, tests they plan to perform and potential implications for services.

When requested and to perform an audit, consent to access required resources will be provided to external security vendor members. {{organization.name}} hereby provides its consent to allow external vendors to access its networks and/or firewalls to the extent necessary to enable the vendor to perform the scans authorized in this agreement. {{organization.name}} shall provide protocols, addressing information and network connection information sufficient for external vendors to utilize the software to perform network and vulnerability scanning and penetration testing. 

This access may include:

  • User-level and/or system-level access to any endpoint or communications devices 
  • Access to information (electronic, hard copy, etc.) that are produced, transmitted or stored on {{organization.name}} equipment or premises 
  • Access to work areas (labs, offices, cubicles, storage areas, etc.)
  • Access to interactively monitor and log the traffic on {{organization.name}} networks 

If a vendor provides {{organization.name}}’s network infrastructure, approval may be required by the third party before scanning can take place.

Network performance and/or availability may be affected by the application and network scanning. {{organization.name}} releases the external security vendor of any and all liability for damages that may arise from network availability restrictions caused by the network scanning within the scope of the agreement, unless such damages are the result of the security vendor’s gross negligence or intentional misconduct. 

All Denial of Service (DoS) testing should be approved each time prior to execution. 

Where third-parties are used for testing, {{organization.name}} shall conclude contracts with these third-parties that stipulate sound management of the test results and that any data processed thereof, including any data that is generated, stored, aggregated, communicated or destroyed as well as any drafts or actual reports, do not create any risks to {{organization.name}}.

3.4 Client Point of Contact During the Scanning Period 

{{organization.name}} shall identify in writing a person to be available if the security vendor requires assistance or has questions based on the results of the vulnerability scans.

3.5 Scanning Period 

{{organization.name}} and the security vendor’s scanning team shall identify in writing the allowable dates for the scan to take place. 

3.6 Risk-Based Testing Approach:

{{organization.name}} shall ensure all digital resilience testing activities are guided by a risk-based approach. This approach shall prioritize systems, applications, and data based on their criticality to the {{organization.name}}'s operations and the potential impact of a security breach. Regular risk assessments shall be conducted to inform the selection of tests, assessments, methodologies, and practices used.

3.7 Tester independence

{{organization.name}} shall ensure testers are not involved in the development, operations, or direct management of systems they are testing

3.7.1 Conflict of Interest

{{organization.name}} shall require testers to declare any potential conflict of interest before the start of testing. If any conflict of interest is declared {{organization.name}} shall replace the tester.
 

3.8 Threat-Led Penetration Testing:

{{organization.name}} may conduct Threat-Led Penetration Testing (TLPT). This will involve simulating realistic threat scenarios based on current and emerging cyber threat intelligence. The objective of TLPT will be to identify vulnerabilities that may be exploited by potential attackers and to assess the potential impact of such attacks on {{organization.name}}'s operations.
 

3.9 Classification, Prioritization, and Remediation of Issues:

Upon completion of each testing activity, {{organization.name}} shall classify all issues identified according to their nature and severity. This classification will inform the prioritization of issues for remediation. High-risk issues affecting critical systems or data shall be addressed as a matter of urgency. {{organization.name}} shall develop a comprehensive remediation plan for each identified issue, detailing the remedial actions to be taken, the parties responsible, and the expected timeframe for resolution.
 

3.10 Internal Validation Methodologies:

{{organization.name}} shall use various methodologies, including, but not limited to, vulnerability scanning, security audits, and incident response simulation, to validate the effectiveness of {{organization.name}}'s digital resilience measures. Any weaknesses, deficiencies, or gaps identified through these methodologies shall be addressed promptly and comprehensively.

The organization protects laptops and workstations and their contents using industry best practices.

","details":"

{{organization.name}} Workstation and Mobile Device Policy

1.0 Purpose

The purpose of this policy is to ensure the security of information residing on workstations and mobile devices, as well as information that users can access through them. 

This policy defines procedures and restrictions for all end-users with legitimate business use connecting mobile devices to {{organization.name}}’s corporate network, digital resources and data. The Workstation and Mobile Device Policy applies, but is not limited to, all devices and accompanying media that fit the following classifications:

  • Laptop/notebook/ultrabook computers
  • Workstations
  • Smartphones
  • Other mobile/cellular phones
  • Tablets
  • Portable media devices
  • Wearable computing devices
  • Any other mobile device capable of storing corporate data and connecting to a network

2.0 Scope

All {{organization.name}} employees, contractors and vendors with {{organization.name}}-owned or personal workstations and mobile devices connected to {{organization.name}} network. 

Applications employees use on their personal devices that store or have access to corporate data, such as cloud storage applications, are also subject to this policy.  

3.0 Policy

Appropriate measures must be taken when using workstations and mobile devices to ensure the confidentiality, integrity and availability of sensitive information. 

{{organization.name}} shall implement safeguards to restrict access to authorized users for all devices with access to corporate information.

Users shall consider the sensitivity of the information that may be accessed and minimize the possibility of unauthorized access. 

3.1 Operational Safeguards

The following operational safeguards shall be implemented:

  • Devices shall be updated regularly with the latest vendor software updates and {{organization.name}} supported OS. 
  • An encrypted password storage solution should be used if users store their passwords on the same device.
  • Enable disk encryption for all devices accessing {{organization.name}}’s resources.
  • Devices shall be configured with a secure password that complies with {{organization.name}}’s policy. 
  • Enable a password-protected screen lock with a short timeout period to protect idle workstations and mobile devices.
  • Only devices managed by IT or authorized by IT shall be allowed to connect directly to {{organization.name}}’s resources. 
  • Install and enable security features such as firewalls, anti-virus and anti-malware software.
  • Restrict access to defined types of digital and/or non-digital media which shall be restricted to  defined personnel or roles.
  • Where applicable, devices shall be subject to security and compliance rules such as encryption, password, key lock, etc. The IT department shall enforce these policies using Mobile Device Management (MDM) software whenever possible.
  • Any attempt to bypass the MDM implementation will result in immediate disconnection from all corporate resources.
  • All personal mobile devices attempting to connect to the corporate network through the internet shall be inspected by {{organization.name}}’s IT department.
  • Devices not supported by IT, are not in compliance with IT’s security policies or represent any threat to the corporate network or data will not be allowed to connect. 
  • If wireless network access is used, ensure secure access using the highest generally accepted wireless security encryption standard.
  • Devices shall access the corporate network and data through the internet using a Secure Socket Layer (SSL) or Virtual Private Network (VPN) connection.
  • Sensitive data such as personal information stored on the mobile devices must  be encrypted. 

3.2 User Requirements

  • Users shall only load corporate data essential to their role onto their workstations or mobile device(s).
  • Users shall report all lost or stolen devices to {{organization.name}} IT immediately. 
  • Suppose a user suspects that unauthorized access to {{organization.name}} data has taken place via a device. In that case, they shall report the incident in alignment with {{organization.name}}’s incident handling process. 
  • Devices shall not be “jailbroken” or “rooted”* or have any software/firmware installed designed to gain access to functionality not intended to be exposed to the user. 
  • Users shall not load pirated software or illegal content onto their devices. 
  • Applications shall only be installed from official platform-approved sources (device stores). Installation of applications from untrusted sources is forbidden.
  • Install security-relevant software and firmware updates within defined time period of the release of the updates.
  • Devices shall be encrypted in line with {{organization.name}}’s compliance standards. 
  • Users should be cautious about the merging of personal and work email accounts on their devices. They must ensure that {{organization.name}}’s data is only sent through the corporate email system. If a user suspects that {{organization.name}}’s data has been sent from a personal email account, either in the body text or as an attachment, they must notify {{organization.name}}’s IT immediately. 
  • For mobile devices, the user is responsible for the backup of their personal data as {{organization.name}} will accept no responsibility for the loss of files due to a non-compliant device wiped for security reasons.
  • Identify the types of installation that is allowed (e.g. security patches or software updates) and prohibit the installation of software that is not specifically approved by the organization

The above requirements will be checked regularly by users and the IT team. Should a device be non-compliant, resulting in losing access to email or data, a device lock or a device wipe will be activated in severe cases. 

3.3 Physical Safeguards

Physical access to workstations and mobile devices shall be restricted to authorized only personnel. Employees shall prevent unauthorized viewing of information on a screen by:

  • Securing devices (screen lock or logout) before leaving the area to prevent unauthorized access. 
  • Enabling a password-protected screen saver with a short timeout period ensures that devices are protected when left unattended.
  • Keeping food and drink away from devices to avoid accidental spills. 
  • Securing laptops that contain sensitive information by using cable locks or locking laptops up in drawers or cabinets. 
  • Ensuring that screens/monitors are positioned away from public view. If necessary, install privacy screen filters or other physical barriers to public viewing. 

3.4 Mobile Device Management Remote Wipe

By connecting to {{organization.name}} technology resources, mobile devices gain the capability of being wiped remotely by {{organization.name}} IT department.

When the user or the IT department initiates a remote wipe, the user’s mobile device will be wiped off all data and settings. Wiping data, documents, files, settings and applications in the event a device is lost, stolen or compromised in any way is critical to protecting our company and its confidential data.

{{organization.name}} recommends that users backup personal data frequently to minimize loss if a remote wipe is necessary.

A remote wipe will only be initiated if IT deems it appropriate. Examples of situations requiring remote wipe include, but are not limited to:

  • A lost, stolen or believed to be a compromised device
  • A device that contains an app known to have a security vulnerability
  • A device that is not compliant and or does not grant inspection with the {{organization.name}}’s policy
  • The device belongs to a user that no longer works with or has exited  {{organization.name}}
  • Termination of employment in which the user has not already cleared all {{organization.name}} data by another method approved by IT

3.5 Management and Administration 

The IT department shall ensure that workstations and mobile devices have all critical security updates patched and installed promptly.

The Acceptable Use policy stipulates constraints and practices that users must agree to to access a corporate network and other organizational assets.

","details":"

{{organization.name}} Acceptable Use Policy

1.0 Purpose

The purpose of this policy is to outline the acceptable use of {{organization.name}}’s computing and network resources (IT resources) as well as other organizational and supporting assets. These rules are in place to protect the employee and {{organization.name}}, as inappropriate use exposes {{organization.name}} to risks including virus attacks, compromise of systems and services, and legal issues.

2.0 Scope

This policy applies to employees, contractors, consultants, temporaries, and other workers at {{organization.name}}, including all personnel affiliated with third parties. This policy also applies to all IT resources owned or leased by {{organization.name}}.

3.0 Policy

3.1 General Use and Ownership

Users of {{organization.name}}’s IT resources are expected to abide by the following guidelines that are built around the underlying principles of acceptable use of organizational assets:

  • Comply with all local and applicable international laws.
  • Comply with the customer’s contractual security obligations and requirements.
  • Comply with all information security policies, regulations, procedures, and rules.
  • Respect and protect the intellectual property rights of {{organization.name}}, its customers and other users within {{organization.name}}.
  • Refrain from sharing passwords or accounts with anyone, including trusted friends or family members. Users will be held responsible for any actions performed using their accounts. 
  • Apply the same level of etiquette in all communication using {{organization.name}}’s IT resources to all non-electronic communication.
  • Respect others when using {{organization.name}}’s IT resources.
  • Only access files or data belonging to you or that are publicly available or where the owner of the data has permitted you to access them. 
  • Use corporate email accounts, internet IDs and web pages for corporate communications.
  • Use the internet/intranet and electronic communication judiciously. The distribution of any information through the internet, computer-based services, email, and messaging systems is subject to the scrutiny of the IT team and Security team. {{organization.name}} reserves the right to determine the suitability of this information.
  • While {{organization.name}}'s IT department desires to provide a reasonable level of privacy, users should be aware that the data they create on the corporate systems remains the property of {{organization.name}}.
  • Employees must use extreme caution when opening email attachments received from unknown senders, as such email attachments may contain viruses or other malware.

3.2 Prohibited Usage of {{organization.name}}’s IT Resources

The following usages of {{organization.name}}’s IT resources are prohibited. Under no circumstances is an employee of {{organization.name}} authorized to engage in any activity that is illegal under local, state, federal or international law while utilizing {{organization.name}}-owned resources.

The lists below are by no means exhaustive but attempt to provide guidelines for activities that fall into the category of unacceptable use:

  • Circumvention of any security measure of {{organization.name}}, its customers or other entities.
  • Intentionally interfering with the network’s regular operation, including the propagation of computer viruses and sustained high volume network traffic that substantially hinders the network performance.
  • Violations of the rights of any person or organization protected by copyright, trade secret, patent or other intellectual property, or similar laws or regulations, which includes but is not limited to, the installation or distribution of "pirated" or other software products that are not appropriately licensed for use by {{organization.name}}.
  • Unauthorized copying of copyrighted material including, but not limited to, digitization and distribution of copyrighted sources and the installation of any copyrighted software for which {{organization.name}} or the end-user does not have an active license is strictly prohibited.
  • Revealing or publicizing {{organization.name}}’s confidential or proprietary information, which includes, but is not limited to: financial information, new business and product ideas, marketing strategies and plans, databases and the information contained therein, customer lists, technical product information, computer software source codes, computer/network access codes, and business relationships.
  • Visiting internet sites that contain obscene, hateful or any objectionable material.
  • Making or posting indecent remarks, proposals or materials on the internet.
  • Downloading any software or electronic files without implementing anti-virus protection measures approved by {{organization.name}}.
  • Intentionally using, distributing or creating viruses, worms or other malicious software.
  • Operating a business, usurping business opportunities, organizing political activity or conducting activity for personal gain.
  • Implying that the user is representing, giving opinions or otherwise making statements on behalf of {{organization.name}} without prior authorization or using. {{organization.name}} trade names, logos, or trademarks without prior written authorization.
  • For business needs and based on approval, if BYOD (Bring Your Own Devices) arrangements are in place, i.e., Personally-owned workstations or mobile devices are used for business purposes, users shall not create or store confidential or sensitive information on personally-owned workstations.
  • To prevent the introduction of malware and information leakage or data loss in {{organization.name}}, the use of USB (Universal Serial Bus) flash drives and any other portable storage media is prohibited unless specifically authorized by the IT department.
  • For solutions to business needs, critical technologies shall not be implemented or installed without explicit approval by the authorized parties to prevent opening gaps that put critical systems and cardholder data at risk.

3.3 Email and Communications Activities

Users of {{organization.name}}’s email and communication resources shall abide by the responsibilities and expected behaviour and refrain from:

  • Sending unsolicited email or other types of electronic messages, including sending "junk mail" or other advertising material to individuals who did not specifically request such material (spam)
  • Using unsolicited emails originating from within {{organization.name}}’s networks or from other internet/intranet/extranet service providers on behalf of, or to advertise, any service hosted by {{organization.name}} or connected via {{organization.name}}’s network
  • Soliciting emails that are unrelated to business activities or for personal gains
  • Sending confidential emails without suitable encryption

3.4 Blogging and Social Media

Blogging and using social media by employees, whether using {{organization.name}}’s property and systems or personal computer systems, are also subject to the terms and restrictions outlined in this policy. Employees must abide by the responsibilities and expected behaviour for use of social media, social networking sites, and external sites/applications. 

Limited and occasional use of {{organization.name}}’s systems to engage in blogging or other social media is acceptable, provided that it is done professionally and responsibly and does not otherwise violate {{organization.name}}’s security policies. Blogging or using social media from {{organization.name}}’s systems is also subject to monitoring.

As such, employees are prohibited from revealing any {{organization.name}} confidential or proprietary information, trade secrets or any other confidential information when engaged in blogging. Employees shall not engage in any blogging or social media use that may harm or tarnish the image, reputation or goodwill of {{organization.name}} and any of its employees.

Employees are also prohibited from making any discriminatory, disparaging, defamatory or harassing comments when blogging or using social media.

Employees may also not attribute personal statements, opinions or beliefs to {{organization.name}} when engaged in blogging or using social media. If an employee is expressing their beliefs or opinions in blogs, the employee should not, expressly or implicitly, represent themselves as an employee or representative of {{organization.name}}. 

Employees assume any risks associated with blogging or using social media.
